transcript_whisper: So I started using drugs when I was 12 years old. Really I just wanted to fit in with everyone, you know, smoking weed and drinking and doing a lot of LSD actually. McShin had one female house and two male houses at the time back in 2007. And I lived here for five months. I worked. I had my driver's license and a car. And now the McShin Foundation, we have 15 recovery homes. We have our women and children recovery house, which I've been wanting to do since the day I started working here. title: David Hill's Story - episode 171

transcript_whisper: I grew up in probably your standard households, you know, two parents, both of master's degrees. We moved around a little bit when I was a kid. My parents were both educators and my dad was really chasing a career, so we moved a little bit. And I always had the sense of I didn't fit in. I was sort of awkward and didn't do well with my peer group necessarily. And so I never really feel like I had a place and or a community. When I was in high school, I felt that I was called to be a nurse. So when I graduated high school, I went to nursing school and had a really great nursing career. I moved away from Texas up to Boston and was doing some nursing consulting work, fell down some stairs and had a back injury and a broken tailbone. So I went to the emergency room and I was immediately prescribed opioids and Xanax to help with pain. And to this day, I'm not really sure why they gave me Xanax, but I took it. But what the experts didn't know was that there was a history of addiction in my family. There is a history of mental health issues in my family. And now we know that there is correlation between people who have addiction and family history and mental health issues. So as much as the doctors did prescribe it and continued to prescribe it for years, they can't be solely responsible because we didn't have all the information that we needed at the time this happened. And also, we can't expect every physician prescribing any type of medication, but especially a controlled substance, to be able to have the time to say, tell me about your family. Is there a history of addiction? And is there a history of mental health issues? I mean, I wish that we had a health system in the United States that did that, but that's not what we currently have. And that's not what we had when I became addicted almost 20 years ago. I still have friends in the medical community and I was in the medical community. So I see both sides, especially now because I have now some personal perspective and some professional perspective and now an expert's perspective on prevention. But with the medical knowledge I have now, I realize that there are a lot of solutions that we could offer to the medical community, but they're not yet at a place to really embrace the solutions. And we're always, this is a change. Change is hard, but it's necessary. Change at the level we're talking about, systemic change is incredibly hard to do. It's incredibly expensive and it takes a lot of voices to get us there. And it's not just the medical community. It's not just your physicians and nurses and pharmacists. It's your pharmaceutical companies. It's your lobbyists. It's your congressmen and it's insurance companies. We need systemic change. The best way I can explain what happened before opioids and what happened after, and maybe, I don't know that it was something that happened to me that I could have changed, but I can tell you that by the third or the fourth day of me using opioids to treat physical pain was that I felt like a light switch had gone on. And all of a sudden, I was seeing the world in different colors. I was not as socially awkward. I felt more comfortable with myself. We moved from, I moved from treating physical pain to treating emotional pain. But the best way I can explain that to someone who maybe has never used drugs or never had my experience was it was like a light switch. And every time I took a pill, I liked the light coming on. And I can tell you, I know the room I was in, the address I was in when I felt that phenomenon for the very first time. It is now a core memory. That first light switch was pretty cool. The ones that followed for a little while still felt pretty good. But at some point, I did definitely develop a tolerance to the medication itself, which is physical tolerance, not an emotional tolerance, although that does come into play. But I was also experiencing withdrawal symptoms when I would stop taking opioids and know whenever had, and even though I was a nurse and could have done my own research on opioids. Know whenever had a conversation with me about, you know, you really need to be cautious when you're taking these medications and this is why. And if you stop taking them abruptly, this is what you're going to experience. And this was at the height of the fentanyl or the opioid crisis in Massachusetts, which is really was super fascinating to me because the doctors were prescribing, but it was the pharmacist who had recently, the state had recently mandated a prescription drug monitoring program or a PDMP. So the doctors were writing the prescriptions as fast as they could. And I was going to as many doctors as I could to get those prescriptions, but it was only the pharmacist saying, I see you got this filled four days ago by another doctor. Why are you coming to me now? Which it's fascinating to me to look back and to know that at the time, you know, the East Coast was experiencing some of the worst years of their opioid crisis. The physicians were not part of the solution, only the person dispensing the actual drug. So the pharmacist caught on. So I had more trouble filling the prescriptions. What does someone do when they can't get their opioids from a medical professional? They find other ways. So I found other ways and started buying up the street. So I, you know, I purchased at the pharmacy and was also, you know, buying on the street. But I did that for probably a year. And then my sister-in-law at the time died of a drug overdose. Of course, now we don't know what, you know, they didn't do a lot of testing. It was just labeled a drug overdose. So we're not even sure what, what the drug was. So I don't know if it was poisoning of a fentanyl or of something else. But I realized that I didn't want to have that happen to me and to my family. But I also didn't know how to do anything differently than I'd been doing for several years at that point. A lot of that recognition came from just the amount of pills I was consuming a day. Because not only did I have, you know, withdrawals when I stopped using, but the physical tolerance just got more and more extreme. And I still have that tolerance to this day. You know, haven't taken, you know, a non-prescribed opioid, I'll say, you know, in over 13 years. But the physical tolerance really became a problem. And I mean, at the end of my active addiction, I was taking upwards of 100 pills a day because I would take so many opioids. Yeah, that they would make me itch. So I would take Benadryl. And the Benadryl, you know, had a side effect, so I would take another pill. And I would, all of this made me edgy, so I would take another pill. So yeah. I was living in Texas again, and I didn't have any pills. And I couldn't get them as easily here as I was able to in Massachusetts. It was, I didn't have maybe the connections that I needed, or it wasn't in the right neighborhood. I'm not really sure. But I just, I couldn't buy off the streets anymore. I just didn't know who to go to and who to ask. So I was really a lot more dependent on getting it from physicians. And Texas didn't have a prescription drug monitoring program at the time. So the pharmacists weren't wise. The physicians weren't aware. So for a long time, I went, I doctor shopped. And the pharmacists couldn't tell where I was getting any prescription. So I would just go to different pharmacies each day, or, you know, every week or so. But at some point, the doctors started suspecting that I might have a addiction problem, but they wouldn't have that conversation with me. They would just say, I'm sorry, I can't prescribe. So there was no conversation of, you may need to let us help you. There was no conversation of, you could really, you could harm yourself. You know, what you could do as an alternative or how they could help. I was just cut off. And so I called in a prescription to the pharmacy myself. And I got arrested at the pharmacy. So I was arrested at the pharmacy. My family at the time, I don't think had any clue as to how extreme my problem was. I know now that they were suspecting, my mom especially was suspecting that there was, you know, some misuse going on. But she had, I don't think she had any, you know, comprehension of how bad the problem was until she got a phone call from the police. So I was arrested. And the condition of me getting out of jail was that I would go to treatment. So within four or five days, I was in a 28 day residential treatment center. And I had the privilege to do that because my family was able to pay the cash to get me into treatment. A lot of people don't have that privilege. So for the first 16 days, I was only there because that's what my family wanted me to do. And then day 17, my head was really starting to clear. You know, more, I had gotten a lot of the drugs out of my system and I was really able to evaluate the situation, you know, a little more objectively and see that I had a lot of consequences and it was going to take a lot of work to overcome them. And some I probably would never overcome. And so day 17 through 28, I probably got the most use out of the cash that was paid. Being arrested was the best thing that's happened to me, which you don't hear a lot. I get it. I work with law enforcement and every time someone hears me say that for the first time, we have to have a conversation about it. So that was interesting. Surgery, you know, after, you know, heavily misusing opioids was a difficult process. But it was when I moved from the Dallas area to San Antonio and I got connected with a 12 step group here, which I'm no longer in the 12 step fellowship, but I think that they can be beneficial. But someone in that group said, we like you should work at a, you would be really great like a treatment center or something. So I applied for a job at Sakata and worked as a recovery coach in the recovery and adult services department for a year. But the work that I was doing was some in the community, you know, going out and meeting partners and doing training with professionals to talk about language we use to educate people about why we say substance use disorders and why that's important and what does the data say. So I really liked the community work. And I really liked then policy, it was policy change. I didn't, I wasn't able to articulate that at the time. But Sakata has a coalitions that work mostly in policy. How do you change a business policy to make things safer? How do you change a bars policy to make things safer? How do you make, how do you change city, county, state or federal policy? So I really thought that that was something that I would be good at doing. And so I, there was an opening in the coalition department and I interviewed and moved departments and that's been five years. The recovery? I wouldn't say that. Not now. I would say that the first one to two years were hard because I was essentially rebuilding an identity and rebuilding a future that was a healthy one. So it was hard because there have to be a lot of changes with friend groups, with communities, with thought process and that is all hard to do. So yes, the first one to two years was hard, but it'll be 14 years in January and I really am not at a place where I count days anymore. I haven't counted days in a long, long time. But now with 13, almost 14 years of perspective, it's not hard at all. It's pretty cool. I get to have relationships with my families that are meaningful. I have the privilege of one of my oldest nieces coming to visit today, or my oldest niece coming to visit today. I have the privilege of taking my youngest niece to the museum that she loves. I get to... You know, I get to care for my aging parents. I would not have had that without recovery.
title: Rebuilding a future

transcript_whisper: I'm here because I want to make a difference. I can't say that I've ever used fentanyl, but heroin was my addiction, and I've been in recovery for seven years. What would you say to someone who's just starting out in recovery? In recovery, I would tell them, don't give up before the miracle happens. The miracle. Yeah. The fire. The fire for recovery. I want to help others. I got clean in prison, but my last use was also in prison as well. When I got out, I went to a recovery house in Columbia and started to see that other people, just as bad as myself, they were killing it, and they were joyful, and they were helping others, and they had a fire about them. I wanted that. My first heroin use was about 16 years old in Cleveland, Ohio, where I'm from. We were doing oxy-cottons, and we didn't have any oxy-cottons, so we did some heroin. That's where my addiction just took off. So there's no going back? No, not after that. How long did that go on? Well, I'm 45, and I've been clean for seven years, so it went on for a couple of decades. In and out of prison, homeless, overdoses, funerals, mental wards, all of it. What helped? The best motivator for anybody to get clean and sober is pain, because you're not going to change if something's going good. You're not going to change if you don't have to. The best motivator for me was pain, shame, and guilt, sitting in a prison cell. My family was done with me, ashamed of me, and I had nobody and no word of turn. That was my motivator to change. When I came home from prison, my sister gave me a chance. Both my parents were passed away. All my grandparents were, but the most important people, my sister, my niece, they started to give me another chance. I started going to recovery meetings and building a family there. I started going to church and building a family there. Building relationships. When you think about addiction, when you think about recovery, I think about what the opposite of recovery is. I think that that is not being connected. I think that's the opposite of addiction. I got connected every way. Like I said, recovery meetings, church, community. I became a peer specialist working with people that are in active addiction or just got clean. I found my niche. What do you do now? You're paying it forward, it sounds like. Paying it forward. Sometimes it sounds really glorious and fun. I'm helping people get cleanest over. When you think of addicts and early recovery, it's not fun. Just because we pulled a needle out of our arm or stopped smoking a bubble or whatever your choice is, it doesn't mean that all your problems go away instantly. All that means is you're not getting high. The real challenge is now, now that you have to deal with yourself and all your trauma and yucky crap that you brought into recovery with you. Many early recovery people, their statistics are not great, but I get those twos and threes and four people that I sit back at the end of the day like, yep, this is why I do what I do. That's the cool part. Rehab, that's a really expensive way to get free information. That's not a popular opinion, but it's the truth. All those resources are out here in the community as well. I do believe that it serves a purpose, it helps them get to dope out of their system. The relapses, maybe it's me being cynical from doing this for a few years now. I expect people to relapse. It makes me extremely joyful when they don't. If I expect them to relapse, it doesn't take away from any effort I put into how I serve them or help them or anything like that, but it's okay. I get it. The most unfortunate thing these days is that when it comes to fentanyl, another recovery is not guaranteed. People are dying left and right, so relapse is not okay. I'll never sit here and be like, well, it's okay. I won't co-sign that. I won't. Relapse is not okay, but it's expected. The last thing that I always remind my guys is that these are not breaking bad characters in a surgical place making this stuff. These are sometimes foreign, sometimes whoever, but they're out here in these woods with stills and all this other stuff, and it's nasty, and there's no method to it. These are not scientists making these pills. Again, that's the scary part. A lot of times they're just junkies trying to get high too. Just because it says Adderall or Morphine or whatever on the pill, that doesn't mean nothing. That means that they bought that pill press off of eBay. What's the big things that people that are in recovery really need to know? What's the things that they don't know? Something I always tell people is get in the middle of the boat. If you're a fellowship person such as myself, you go to as many meetings as possible and you learn how to serve, and you build a support network. If you're not a fellowship person, you better find something to believe in. You better find something to fill that void because us as drug addicts and alcoholics, we live and breathe it. Our addiction is everything. My addiction was the most jealous thing ever. I wasn't allowed to have family, girlfriend, job, none of that. Just my addiction. When you take that addiction out of your life, it leaves a gaping wound, like a void. You need to fill it with something. God, recovery, something positive. Most of us, we're not just addicted to the dope. We're addicted to the life. Got to fill that void. I'm an NA person. I found my family there. I found people like me, knuckleheads, just like myself, that gave me something to do. They held me accountable. They didn't cosign my bullshit anymore. They wouldn't just accept any old answer. They made me really start taking a look at myself and holding me accountable, gave me stuff to do, gave me responsibilities, made me feel a part of their life. That's the biggest thing because we don't use drugs, fentanyl, whatever because we feel great about ourselves. You know what I'm saying? We use to hide this trauma and these feelings. When we start to experience a little recovery and people start accepting us, it means the world. It really does.
title: Mike's Story - The Fires of Recovery

transcript_whisper: It started with drinking first as a teenager. Yes, as a teenager it started with drinking and over the years it progressed and got worse. And it's also miles and miles away from Virginia. So the point of moving away from the area that you're used to and the people that you know was a part of the suggestion of going to Kentucky to kind of start over. And it actually was helpful, very helpful. It was hard to do in the beginning. And as I went through my process, but it was the best decision I ever made in my life. I believe it stuck because I had finally made up in my mind that that's not the life I want to live. I finally made up in my mind that I was tired. I was sick and tired of being sick and tired. I had finally made up in my mind that I want better for myself and my children. So even though I gained a lot of knowledge while being there, I also applied that knowledge. And that's what made it makes it powerful. I had to actually come to the point where, okay, I'm here in the rehab program miles and miles away from my kids and family. Clearly, I don't know a thing about life and how to live. So I had to humble myself. I had to listen to other people that had been there long before me and that were actually walking, walking it out. So I had to shut up, be quiet and take suggestions. I had to be open to that. I had to go into it in a mindset of knowing that, hey, I don't know everything because see, I always thought I knew everything. But I had to get real with me first. Keonjoo, you don't know all there is about how to live life and live it on life terms. So I had to listen. I'm still taking it one moment at a time. I'm taking it one step at a time. transcript_whisper: I Am an alcoholic and an addict I have been in recovery since February 24th of 2023 I Am hoping that just sharing my story will encourage others that recover is possible Yeah, on Saturday, it'll be 18 months And in that time I have been able to Get a lot back that I had previously lost I Have reestablished a connection with my younger sister and her family My mom and I are closer than ever But the catalyst to getting sober for me was unfortunately the death of my father He died on May 8th of 2022 and Before he passed away. I had decided that I wanted to Try to get sober I Signed up for outpatient services at a recovery center here in town and I did successfully complete that and I quit drinking alcohol I haven't had a drink since April 24th of 2022 But in my grief I discovered that I Was not just an alcoholic I would pretty much use anything that I could to Try to tamp down those feelings and grief is an incredibly uncomfortable feeling My dad and I had been very close he Was a pastor here in town he was always just the most honest and understanding man and So I was closer to him than I was to the other members of my family And losing him was really hard so You know because I knew he was sick was when I really started trying but Like I said grief can do some Really hard things to us I Had still been smoking marijuana a lot of people call it marijuana maintenance, you know for some people it is helpful, but for me it It just made things worse it made the anxiety worse it made the depression worse and I Didn't understand that at the time And eventually I started using other substances Because I just figured well, it's not drinking right? so The substance that I had the hardest time with is you know one of the dumbest that you could do I Started huffing air duster Because I knew that it Wasn't a lasting high and I thought well, you know, it's not an illicit substance but What it was doing to my body and my brain was Probably worse than the drinking I Ended up, you know really Doing a lot of damage to My body my brain and you know myself esteem I knew what I was doing was incredibly stupid But at the time it felt like the only way to escape the grief that I was feeling and It was easy to get I Ended up getting to a point with that where I was making myself sick. I was passing out it causes a lack of oxygen to the brain and There are chemicals in it that can potentially do you know damage your lungs among other things and I was To a point with it where my roommates at the time were afraid they were gonna find me dead so In order to You know Keep my job keep my living situation and keep my family I Signed myself up for outpatient services a second time It was actually the third overall but this was the time that I really took it seriously I went to a place here in town called mirror, Inc. They have them across Kansas, but the one here in Topeka was the one that Did the trick for me? I guess so to speak I Had an incredible counselor who tailored my recovery plan to my interests and What interested me was learning about why our Bodies and brains, you know want and crave these substances and what it does to us and I Think understanding and learning about those things really helped me So a lot of my homework was watching documentaries But I also just I Started taking notes I started really investing, you know more time in the hows the wise and the what's and Something clicked and stuck and Now that I do know Exactly what I was doing to myself looking back. It's scary But at the time that was all I knew I had been drinking and using different substances since I was about 13 years old It started when my family was living in Oklahoma City We moved back to Topeka. I was born here, but we moved back to Topeka around the time that I was 16 and For my generation drugs are everywhere They're easy to get it's scarier all the time I Have been drinking heavily essentially since I started drinking I Was somebody who drank to escape Or to fit in, you know, I always had to keep up with everybody and So that was a point of contention in my family and You know, my parents really tried they tried to understand they tried to get me help they You know, they knew that something was going on but Nobody is ready to see it until they're ready Nobody can get you sober except you The heavy drinking was I think the hardest because For a long time, you know, I knew that I was doing it as an escape, but I wasn't Looking at why I needed to escape And that's something that in my adult life I have focused more on Recovery for me does include a lot of therapy I I Didn't want to see it as a teenager though who wants to you know have a problem who wants to admit that they're different Whether it's substance use disorder a diagnosable mental health disorder, you know, nobody there's a stigma surrounding all of those things and And at the same time there's a bunch of people around you in school who are doing similar things Right as a kind of endorsement. Yeah of doing it and you know going from Everybody else doing it because it's cool to experiment in school. I went into the surface industry Where drinking and drug use are encouraged? It doesn't matter what kind of day you've had what kind of shift you've had you drink about it and There's also a lot of access to other substances In my 20s, especially it was drinking and cocaine I am very grateful that at the time Fentanyl wasn't as big a thing as it is now Because with the way that I was drinking and using I could have easily fallen victim to something like that It really started just as experimentation, you know in Middle school that was mostly just smoking pot in high school. It was drinking at parties And then it was harder drugs I Tried meth for the first time when I was 15 years old and It was because people had it I Trusted them. I wanted to try it So we're winding a little bit when I was 14. I was sexually assaulted and I think that The trauma from that really affected the Experimentation it went from I'll try it to Let's do it all the time because what could hurt me that didn't already hurt me and My parents knew that something was going on, but I didn't tell them for about a year that anything had happened and When they did find out It was after a particularly big explosion of emotion That was due to drinking And like I said my parents always tried you know, but The help that they wanted to get me I wasn't ready to take I was too angry at the world to do anything about it yet I'm still working on getting past that still angry at the world a little bit More so the trauma of that specific event. I'm less angry at the world and I am more angry at myself for Not Trying when help was offered. I Think a lot of addicts in recovery Have ourselves first on our resentment lists I Think it's a very personal thing if you prefer to refer to yourself as someone with substance use disorder That's all right. If you prefer to call yourself an addict. That's all right Recovery is personal and how we label ourselves as personal I Really appreciate people who have dedicated their lives to learning about addicts and substance use disorder and working with them, but Unless you have that lived experience It's not really up to you what we call ourselves Recovery is possible It's a lot of hard work There are days where You feel like why am I doing this? but It's really powerful to know that you can get through those days without using The life that I live now is The life that I've always wanted but I Was too afraid of feeling and doing the inner work for so long that It's a little postponed But just because it's postponed doesn't mean it's not beautiful Seeing The change in myself has been incredible when I started my recovery journey I started journaling and Looking back at the things that I used to write about and You know how that has evolved is Sort of like this tangible proof of life that I can hold in my hand and see You know just how far I have come in this process You

transcript_whisper: Way back in probably 2009, it started out with weed and alcohol. Back then it was in and out of jail and group homes because it was just trouble after trouble after trouble. We moved down to Texas in a small town called Eustace. That was at about 14. It was a small town of probably just a couple hundred people. I had my best friend down there and we smoked weed every day. All day that was our thing. One day we got a hold of some acid. We did the acid. We were told that if you smoke some meth with the acid that it gives you a better time. It gives you a better ride. We did it. At the time we thought it was great. It was fun. We got expelled and then went even further because now we don't have really any responsibility. At 16 you don't have school and what not it's what it is. We got pretty far off there. I ended up getting sent to KJCC here in Topeka and whenever that happened I got out right before my 18th birthday so Texas ended up dropping all their stuff because I already went to prison up here and stuff for it. I was there for like three months and I ended up getting into a fight and got kicked out of there. So then I went back to the Wyandotte County JDC and they sent me back to KJCC for three months. Three months at that time because I was still, actually I went to the county jail at that point. I was over 18. But I was still on juvenile stuff so they sent me back to KJCC. I got out after doing three months. This brings us up to the end of 2016, beginning of 2017. I went to live with my grandma and I did pretty well for a little while. It gave me something to kind of look forward to. I was part-time at Johnson County Community College for automotive tech. It seems like once the summer break hit, it just all hell broke loose again. It was very slow because I was trying to not lose everything. I thought that there was a way to do it and not get caught, not get in trouble. This brings us to mid-17. And finally, I lost my job. My juvenile probation violated, went to the county and the juvenile court gave me an unsuccessful discharge. I looked at that as a hell yeah at the time. I don't even got to sit in jail no more. transcript_whisper: For me working all 12 steps and sponsoring people today is really a whole lifestyle change. Being a service to others in any way I can and it's the career path I took now and it's been really rewarding. Just one of the main reasons that keep me sober today is being a service to others. So the things I get to do in my community now is I work with a non-profit agency and I do parent education and parent leadership. So being me in a person in recovery is I reach out to the people I can help the most who can relate to my stories and our parents, you know, the people that have kids involved and really get to reach out to them and make a difference in their lives. I had an opiate issue for almost 15 years when I first started doing it. I was about 14 and that's when it wasn't an issue but it gradually got worse and worse. One of the big things that got me sober was actually surviving an overdose on fentanyl. That's when I knew that things, I was Narcan by a friend who isn't here today now because of an overdose and I mean he saved my life that day and that's when I knew that I had to change it for my kids and myself because I wanted to be the father that they needed. And back then it seemed like, you know, just grabbing stuff out of your parents' cabinets or buying them at school and stuff like that but I was prescribed Adderall at a young age in a fetamines and it's something I realized I could trade for what I wanted because I found my love in opiates instead of, you know, that and it just kind of blend over to that line and it wasn't really an issue. High school was the weed, the drinking and the pills really, you know, and started, you know, dabbling in psychedelics and stuff like that but nothing seemed like an issue at the time, you know, and I got married at a young age right out of high school and that's when the whole journey with synthetic opioids at least really took off and I don't know whether, when the withdrawal started or when it really started going downhill is just, I can't place it but it turned into a problem, a huge problem in my life. It's somewhere in the line of when I started distributing, when I had them around me a lot more I'd say and that's when I had more access and it became more of a problem where I, you know, I didn't have to pay for them or have to go out and do things, you know, and it's just, it was a slope that went downhill pretty fast. I've always been a true alcoholic too and it's it runs in my family also with addiction and mental health and stuff so those were all huge things and of course getting in trouble with the law. I remember I failed probation just because of substance use. I remember going in there and I would admit to the opiate use because he knew that I was an opiate addict but that was just to keep him from finding, you know, the other three or four drugs I was on at the time also because a lot of it was couch surfing at the time and just following that road. It eventually led me to prison and being released from prison I maxed my time out and the year post release I'd say within two days of release, you know, I was sticking needles in my arm again and it was immediately downhill for a couple months and I broke down to my parole officer and I was like I need help. I can't stop and they were really good about it and put me in treatment here and you know that time I survived a good 18 months over. I am a huge advocate for Oxford houses too. I've been in Oxford houses probably five years and all. This time I stayed a good 16 months I believe that time and it eventually came down to wanting visits with my older daughter and she was born in that marriage and I got divorced from that marriage and I didn't have a safe place for her to be while I was working on my recovery so I ended up moving in with a friend and I told myself I was a normal drinker that I could have just one and be fine and all that and about three years later I crawled back and I was having alcohol related withdrawal seizures and every time I really wasn't dabbling into opiates but every time I tried to pick one up I would overdose and it happened twice before I really realized that this isn't the same anymore. It looked the same as it used to be but it just fell out immediately and stopped breathing and it's like that's not how it used to be and it's just not worth it no more. And unfortunately it was a friend that ended up passing from fentanyl overdose who saved me. He died about it's almost two years on those two close friends I lost. My best friend since I was five he died about 18 months ago from a fentanyl overdose and it's just really something that I tried to dive into harm reduction right then and get the word out because I was tired of losing people. I ended up putting him on my arm and says no story should end too soon. Purple ribbon and everything and I just wanted to take him on this journey with me too and I mean being around people that are losing kids to it and friends and family members it's just it's overwhelming sometimes. So the crazy thing is I got sober during COVID which was a really weird time and like the opposite of what everyone else is doing. But yeah almost dying was really that turning point I did it wasn't on probation or anything at the time. It had somebody telling me to do this. I was just scared for my life. I ended up checking in I had to do a medical detox because the way I was drinking. But with COVID they would set the bed date so far out. It'd be a month until you can get into a bed after the detox. The first time I went to detox it was you know I started drinking again because that bed date and I showed up at that bed date you know drunk and they didn't let me in. So I am so grateful for my parents today because after the second time I went to detox. I'll call it like a passive kidnapping. They took me into their house and you know took my keys to my car everything and would transport me to work just so I could stay good until that time. Until that new bed date and that might have changed everything for me. I did a 30 day program here in Topeka. Immediately went back to Oxford House. So I've been in recovery quite a few times at this point and the one thing I noticed that I didn't do was dive into the program of Alcoholics Anonymous and work these steps. So that's just something that I put in my head like hey I got a really good sponsor. I'm going to actually try to do it this time and he immediately put me into service work. So like I said last time I couldn't have any more safe to raise my kid while working in program recovery which led me into this opportunity of opening the first men in Children's Oxford House in Topeka. So this gave us a safe place to me and a couple dads to bring our kids over there, live in an Oxford House like other people do but also have our kids and it really set off this whole journey. So this whole time I took on my, she was probably two at the time, my little daughter Ava and I took her on full time while working in program and everything and working and doing the whole thing. It's just been such a blessing to watch these other dads thrive in these conditions. A lot of them want to be the parents they can be but they just don't know how to safely go about it in these homes or just a safe place to do that. It's been a recovery process plus you can have your kids around you. The other houses will allow that but we work with companies, not companies but organizations like KVC and state agencies to bring kids home from foster cares using these homes to reintegrate them and it's just been nonstop fulfilling this. I don't know how to describe it. It's really what led me into the career I have right now. I get to do parent education in my community and like I said it's a lot of the people I reach out to are the people that have been incarcerated or have mental health problems, have kids in state custody, dealing with substance abuse, just everything I can relate to. The courses I get around in the community now too because I learn off of fathers every day. I don't know at all. I don't think anybody's got parenting down. It's a new journey every day and it's being around especially the fatherhood stuff I do out here. It's being around other people that are going through it because a lot of it can be scary. Just having someone to talk to about it means the world to people. You don't have to be defined by your past. You can still make a difference out here. It took me, I had to work on myself for a long time to be able to figure out who I am and be able to move forward with my life and I do attribute that a lot to the 12 steps. Being able to sponsor people now, being a service to others, it's just a huge thing that opens doors and it's hard to describe it but there's just signs all around me that show me where I need to be and what I need to be doing. There's got to be this kind of, like in the course of your recovery journey, there's got to be these awesome little discoveries that happen fairly regularly where you see yourself, oh wow, that's better now. The promises of the program, it can be the smallest things at first like, hey I just got my driver's license back, all these, really learning how to adult again, you know, it's like I wasted so much time doing what I wanted instead of what was good for me and those small successes like that, like getting a visit with your kid after you haven't seen them in months, you know, or a driver's license, getting your social security car back, getting your first job while in recovery, it's just the promises of the program and they just keep building and building and repealing themselves.
title: Nathan's Story - In Service to Others

transcript_whisper: Why am I here? So I spent 36 years of my life in addiction, 33-time convicted felon, 28 and a half years of my life in prison. The first thing I would say is that I used to be part of the problem, the drug problem. In 2017 God revealed himself to me. I surrendered my life to Christ. I went back to prison for two years, two and a half years. I came home from prison January 20th or January 2020 and three months later they found my sister dead in a hotel. title: Addiction to Recovery - Paul's Mission

transcript_whisper: I have found freedom for the first time in my life after over 20 years of struggling in alcoholism and substance abuse, specifically meth addiction, and I am in recovery and I'm proudly in recovery. It's taken me a long time, a lifetime, actually a lifetime of relapse, incarceration, trying over and over and over again to find this freedom and I found it. I have found it. My childhood in upbringing was actually fairly normal. I grew up in a house, my parents were divorced, but that's super normal, right? Most parents are divorced these days and I didn't get heavily involved into alcohol until about my freshman year of high school and that was when I first discovered that alcohol made me feel powerful. It took away some of the pain of some of the struggles that I had been experiencing. One of the key moments in my life where things shifted for me, it seems like we all have those key moments in our lives where something happens in our teenage years and this is mine. My mom sent me to go live with my dad. I was 16 years old. I lived with him for about eight months and I was a little wild. I was a little wild and it was too much for my dad and my stepmom and they sent me back to live with my mom and the way that my 16-year-old brain interpreted that moment was that I wasn't good enough and that I didn't deserve a better life, that I...that's the best way to say it, that I just wasn't good enough. I dropped out of school when I got back to Texas after I had come back home to Texas and started drinking very heavily. I was hiding alcohol in my closet and it was a very short time before I was doing cocaine on a regular basis. I did manage to enroll into college throughout that time period but that didn't last because I was way too focused on having fun and drinking. And then there's a moment where it was no longer fun. And I think for people who don't have addiction issues, that's when they stop. And I didn't have an off button. I didn't know that I didn't have an off button but I didn't have an off button and I got involved with meth at around 21 years old and very shortly started shooting meth right after that time and committing crimes to support my habit and was just living that hard and rough lifestyle. It wasn't until I was 24 years old that things started to look up for me. I, through the midst of my addiction, got pregnant, which was an absolute saving grace for me. transcript_whisper: I'm here because I care very much about people that have went through the recovery process, people who have experienced loss due to substance use or abuse, and our future in regards to children that are coming up and being exposed to substances as part of growing up in a part of life. So I work at a prevention agency and being here not only supports the community and the message that is so important to the agency I work for and myself, but it speaks to how big of an issue this is and how many families are being impacted by fentanyl and overdose and substances in so many different ways. I think it's much bigger than we realize, but then I sometimes encounter people that have no idea. And then I am first a bit shocked and then a bit scared thinking how can we get this message out? How can we get more people to have an awareness and an understanding that this is a really very serious crisis and could be far more impactful than we've even seen so far. We lost over 106,000 people in 2023 across the United States. That is down a slight bit from 2022. I think a lot of those numbers are still a bit preliminary. It's hard to get final numbers with all of the work that goes into that. I think that we have areas in Kansas, particularly, that are more impacted. Our county, is Shawnee County, where the capital city is located. We're one of the top counties in Kansas that's impacted by overdoses. We have other counties that have big populations such as Sedgwick County with Wichita and Johnson County with Kansas City that are more significantly impacted than us. They're also larger, but it's alarming how predominant it is in Kansas. We have seen a decrease from 2022 to 2023 of about 4% in overdose fatalities, but we need those numbers to be significantly lower. Fewer families impacted. I think the cost of a human life is too much to measure. A lot of what we focus on in our organization is education of youth. We are in a lot of schools in our community thanks to funding from so many grants. We're able to go out and talk to kids about different substances and the impacts that they can have on their lives from their minds, their bodies, their ability to do athletics and the things that they love to do. We talk about the impacts on relationships and how substances can really impact people there. We also work on educating families and the community through different events where we go out and we talk about whether we have speakers come in or we go out and talk about the impacts of substances on people, whether it be fentanyl or stimulants. We talk about how to recognize signs of overdose, how to respond appropriately, how to administer naloxone. Really being a resource in our community in terms of helping people to understand what to do that this is not something that's isolated to certain families. It can impact anyone from a baby to a senior citizen. This doesn't choose. So education is the largest portion of what we do in our agency. We also do evaluations or assessments to really try to intervene early. A lot of those are with youth that are referred to us from schools that have been caught within a substance of some kind or under the influence of a substance of some kind. We are a stop that helps determine if they need more assistance, whether that be mental health support, whether that be support with substance use, really education for the family and the young person. That's a lot of what we do. I think people get wrong that they think that it could not happen in their family. That's not going to happen in our family. I think people think that individuals with a substance use disorder choose to have that life. They choose to use substances. They choose to live that way. What they really need to know is that we're dealing with individuals that are dealing with trauma, with crisis, with mental health disorders, with real human problems that all of us face. And maybe they don't have the skills at that moment or maybe they don't have the supports at that moment to be able to move forward. But substance use is something that can impact all of us. Overdose can impact all of us. And we just need to really have that awareness that none of us are immune to this occurring in our lives. We do not have enough resources. I really believe that we have got to have more resources. We need to have resources for people that are underinsured or not insured. We need to have access available when people are ready. Because I can't force someone to be ready. You can't force someone to be ready. They have to decide when they're ready. And when they're ready, we need to have a place available for them. And we need to be able to support them and walk with them and help them to get to the other side of this challenge that they're facing. And it may take multiple times, but they need the love and the support. Sometimes that's tough love to get through it, because it is something that you can recover from. Recovery is possible. I know people that have been in recovery for years. And I know people that are very new to recovery. And there's really nothing quite like carrying their stories and knowing the challenges that they've overcome and how their lives have changed so much. And the work that they're doing on the other side is so phenomenal. I'm so proud of my friends that are in recovery. I do see a lot of people that are have found great support in AA or NA. I also feel like there's people that have found their way through other programs, Smart Recovery. I think it impacts everybody different. Everybody needs to find the way that's going to be most successful for them. I feel like that network of support is pivotal. And AA does a great job of really wrapping themselves together as a community and supporting one another. And I think that is really pivotal for people that are in recovery is being able to relate to others that have had this similar experience, have walked through some of the same challenges, dealt with some of the same hurts. And knowing that you can call upon those people at any time has to be tremendous. So I think really whatever way people can find the greatest support forward is going to be huge. I think you reach out, you find a trusted person, you find whether that be someone in your family, whether that be a community resource, whether that be someone that's a trusted friend to walk with you, to help get you there, to drive you to the center, to be your cheerleader and support in the car, to hold your hand, to get you to whatever that place may be. And don't be afraid to reach out. I think that stigma keeps that from happening a lot of times. People are afraid, are nervous about how people might respond to reaching out to wanting to get help. And we've got to just really break that down and really work on supporting people, to getting to where they need to go, calling those numbers, getting in the car, going to the ER, going to the crisis center, going, you know, if there is a place, if you don't know where to go, just reach out to a friend, reach out to someone that can help get you there.

And now for the last 11 years for me, I think. I don't know because I think if you try to remember your sobriety date, I think that in my head, some people, it might work different. But in my head, I would be dwelling on it. And it might trigger me to do it again. He doesn't know his sobriety date because he isn't paying attention to things like that either. But we're sober. And the way we did that was I told him, I'm taking the kids. And I'm moving to Chilli Coffee away from all of this. Either go or you don't go. And I gave him two weeks to get all that out of his system. And he's like, I don't know. It scares me. It scares me to stop because I don't know who I am without this. And I'm like, well, I know who you are. I see it. And I want you to see it. And so I just got in the car. Wasn't very nice getting ready to leave. Flipped out on his mom. And I got in the car and loaded up the kids. And I said, I'm gone. This is your final chance. And he's like, fine. I'll leave it all. Good. Let's go. And we went out to Chilli Coffee. We started our lives over. He had a few struggles here and there. But we found a good church that we went to and got the kids back in church. And all of our kids ended up living with us. And we had Kaley. We had Becca, Billy, Nick, Mary, Frankie. And then ended up pregnant with Chevy. And life is great. And then we moved a little further out to Brookfield, Missouri. The kids loved it there. It's so rural. I really miss it. So does he and so do the kids. And it's kind of harder to find a church there that we felt wasn't judgy because he's covered in tattoos. And I have tattoos, but they're hidden. So you kind of feel judged some places you go. And so it was a little harder for us to do that. But I got really involved in community. Girl Scouts, the girls making sure that the boys had everything that they wanted to be involved in because I did mess up so much of their life. I wanted to fix it. They got real involved in sports and made a lot of friends. And it was the life that I saw and that I had when I was younger. And now we finally did it. We finally did that. And then we ended up out here in Topeka. Billy moved out here. He got a job at my oldest son. Kaylee and Becca would go back and forth between our house and their mom's house. And it was crazy. It was a wild one hell of a ride. I'll say that. But through all of it, God pulled us through it. He never left us because if he did, there's so many circumstances that neither one of us would be here. A lot of people in addiction lose their kids. And that breaks my heart because your kids are always on your mind whether you're high or not. And you just don't want to go around them like that. You can't love yourself enough to get out of it. Makes it a lot harder to be there for your kids. And then you feel like you don't even love your kids enough. Like you're a piece of shit. You can't even love your kids enough to straighten your life out. Like who are you? But then when you do, when you finally realize that you are enough, and you're perfect the way that God made you, and nothing at all can tear you away from that, and everybody makes mistakes. Everybody does. And it's just where you go from there. You can bounce up and down and back and forth. And none of that matters because the goal, if you keep your eye on the prize, you're going to get it in the end. You're going to get it. And that's where we're at now. We busted our butts to get here. But now we have our family, and we've done really good things for our community. And we raise our kids in church. No, Sunday school teacher. I'm a cussie one, apparently. But I work in the nursery at our church, kindergarten, or birth to kindergarten. And I get to teach them a Sunday school lesson every Sunday. And my kids go down, and they're very involved in church. And yeah, and so is Max. So, dun-dun-da. Kept my eye on the prize, and it was a hell of a ride. But here we are. And I've never talked about my addiction. I was weird. Never done that. Never talked to anybody about it, because I just keep it hidden, because people look at you weird. Was I looking at you weird? No. Yeah, it was. You might have been.

And I carried that with me. I carried that feeling, um, that hope for recovery and what it could be. Um, and I still have that today and my barrel will run us over. You know, um, it does. I'm so happy. Um, my life is really good. I have great people in my life today. Um, yeah. Um, yeah.

title: Recovery - Ricardo Bustos-The Son's Story

transcript_whisper: There's a big mystery in this field because it's so disastrous, it's so horrendous, including being measured by overdose deaths, but also the disruption of people's lives, which is so profound and destructive. And you say, well, how does that happen? Why don't people avoid that? I mean, it's clearly, seeing somebody who's life has been taken over by drugs is not a pretty sight. And it's something everybody's seen. And the answer is that this problem is cunning, baffling, and powerful. And the seduction into it is a pretty regular feature. And it isn't, you know, you don't start off by catastrophic events. You start off using drugs with friends, people you know and spend time with. It's not malicious. They're sharing something that is fun that they've had a good time with. And almost invariably, it starts with kids. And the younger they are, the more vulnerable they are. So you get lots of kids who start at 12 and 13, which surprises a lot of people, but that is a very common time to start drugs. And it's not malevolent. It's not started by the drug users. It's started by the drug users who are friends. And they're not meaning to hurt anybody else. They've found something that's fun for them. Nothing bad has happened to them. And they share it with another young person. And that begins the journey. Now, how does it go? Well, it isn't everybody who's going to die of an overdose, but a lot of people do. And sometimes they'll die very early in it, but not often. Most overdoses are in people in their 20s, 30s, and 40s, not among kids. It does happen to kids. And kids do die also. But it's a seduction. And as it goes along, a couple of things happen that are very important. One is that people use more of the drug, and they also spread it to doing other drugs. And it isn't as if it's all just about marijuana or cannabis. Oftentimes that's a starter. Alcohol can be a starter. Cigarettes can be a starter, or nicotine. But it's a whole array of chemicals and lots of different effects of it. But they all have one thing in common. And that is they change the brain, and mostly they work by triggering pleasure and very intensely much more than anything else. And so that's how people get into it. And what's amazing to me about it also, and first of all, that inter-attection, that's remarkable how it is, how even though the people have seen bad things happen to other people, the people they're dealing with have not had bad things happen to them. The down and out addict is not spreading the disease because nobody wants to look like him or her. It's the people who are starting out in it, who are doing it, and it's fun and it's something new. But the other thing that is really very interesting about this is when people have had a lot of problems with drugs and bad things have happened to them, and they go into a rehab and they come out and they're not using drugs, you think that what would happen at that point would the person would say, wow, that was a bad thing I got into. I'm never going to do that again. And yet the most common outcome of rehab is relapse. The percentage of people who relapse is very, very high, way over half, and usually pretty quickly. Sometimes it takes a while, but oftentimes it doesn't. Now how can that be? How can you have a person who has been rescued from chemical slavery and has a clear path ahead of him or her is going to go back to using? That doesn't make any sense at all. That's again this cunning, baffling, and powerful disease. It takes over the person's thinking. And of course the first time the person uses, oftentimes nothing terrible happens, but very quickly they go back into it again. And I gave the example of the first time, how about the tenth time they've been in rehab? It still is like that. So okay, Bob Buchbauer, you've been about this for a long time. What do you do about that? What does that mean? Well, first of all, what it means to me is most people doing treatment programs, I'm not going to say they don't know about relapse, but they underestimate it. They've been the best for the people there, and then some people do stop. It does. But what's missing in that is that the person isn't fixed. It isn't like you've had a disease, and you've gone in and you've gotten disease taken care of, and it's gone. It's not gone. And that's because the brain doesn't forget. And the slippery slope is there, and people will do it over and over again. What can it be done to stop that? Well, there are sort of two basic ways of doing it. One is that people can use medications to deal with opiates, and they can stay on the medications like the methadone, for example, or buprenorphine. And that'll help, but there's still a lot of people that will go on. And now, what I'm going to tell you now, it took me 20 years in this field to come to this, because when I started, I didn't know what Alcoholics Anonymous was. I didn't know what Narconics Anonymous was. I knew about treatment. I'm a doctor. That's something else that's over on the other side. That's, I wouldn't say it's voodoo, but it's not science. It's not what I was interested in. But I had the benefit of having my own patients that I worked with over the course of many years. And these patients educated me. I remember one patient looked at me in the eye, and if we'd come in for several times, he says, doc, I don't think you really get this. Now, I'm a former White House drug czar. I'm a professor of psychiatry at Georgetown Medical School. And this patient says to me, you don't get it. Well, he was right, and I was wrong. And I didn't get it. And I'm appreciative of the other people in the field who don't get it. God bless them, because I was certainly there. So what is this discovery that I've made? Well, I'm proud to be an American for a lot of reasons. I'm actually pretty patriotic and a lot of respect for the country. But one of the things that I'm most proud about as an American is what happened in Akron, Ohio in the summer of 1935. And that was the creation of Alcoholics Anonymous by a salesman and surgeon who had had long-term problems with alcohol and who developed a strategy for dealing with that called Alcoholics Anonymous. Alcoholics Anonymous then, because it had what they called single as a person, they were just talking about alcohol. That's the way they started. But they found out that a lot of people were using other drugs, and even after they stopped drinking, they would use the other drugs and have problems with them. So they discovered it was one problem, and they started another program called Narcotics Anonymous, which was the drug side of it. So the two of them together. And people go back and forth between those two very easily, because they're basically using the same approach. They're two 12-step programs, is what they're called. And this is the perfect American gift to the world, because there's no money involved. The richest person goes to the same meetings as the poorest person. You don't have to have health insurance. It doesn't cost anything. Nobody is getting paid. There's no boss. There's no training program for it. There's no license. No certification. It's just people getting together to help each other using a system that was developed initially in Akron, Ohio in 1935. That's amazing. And it's not a fix. Nobody, everybody in AA and NA knows there's no fix. You're going to have that problem for the rest of your life. Now you can manage it, and the key to manage it is not using. Not using it all. Not cutting down. Not stopping this drug or that drug. And by the way, all the scientists do single drugs. All our diagnoses, you know, opiate use disorder, alcohol use disorder, cannabis use disorder. But the patients aren't one drug. Any drug will do. So recovery means none at all. Zero. And why do they do that? Because they've discovered that using any of the drugs is triggering the same brain mechanism and it's subject to the relapse and all the things that come from that. And the other thing that I had no idea of all my years of practice and seeing patients and everything, didn't understand this. There's a lot more wrong with the person who's using drugs and has an addiction problem than that you're using drugs. And if there's a lot more right with a person in recovery, they're not using drugs. The person who's using drugs to the level of creating the kind of problem that we're calling addiction is a different person. And that person is self-centered, difficult to deal with, all kinds of things that are involved in that character of that person. And when that same person is in recovery, they're generous. They think about other people. There's a whole different person that you're dealing with. It's part of the miracle of recovery and it's a wonderful gift to the world. Now somebody can say to me, okay, Bob DuPont, so you've had this lightning strike you and you've seen all this, but this is just something over the side. What's really going on to deal with this epidemic hasn't to do with those meetings. It has to do with this medicine or this vaccine or whatever it is that's going on, coming from science. I say, okay. But 30 years into the field, I asked myself, how good could outcomes be? Because the most striking thing about treatment of addiction is relapse. This is a disease. How could it possibly be? What would be the best it ever is? And I had the experience in my practice of having doctors as patients who were going to the state physician's health programs. Now a doctor in this country who has an alcohol or drug problem is going to go to the Board of Medicine where their license is. And they're going to get referred to the state physician's health program. Every state has got a physician's health program. And they're all different, but they're all the same also. And they'll do an evaluation of the doctor, the physician. Does he or she have a substance use disorder? If they do, then they're going to go to intensive treatment, typically a 30-day or 60-day or 90-day residential, but it could be outpatient. But anyway, they decided this is the best treatment for this person. And then for five years, five years, they're going to be subject to random testing so that every day for five years, they're subject to be testing and they're done on a random basis. And they get up in the morning and they see whether they have to have testing or not. This is every doctor in the country has this system. It's what they deal with. And then after five years, if they haven't used any drugs and had any problem there, and if they have a relapse, then they're going to go back to treatment again. Okay, how do they do with that? Now think about this. So first of all, I'll tell you that half of them roughly are alcohol of the doctors. A third are opiates and a sixth is everything else. So mostly it's opiates and alcohol that are being treated. And the treatment is the same for both. Same for both. Okay. 78% of those doctors never had a single missed or positive test in five years. Now think about that in relation to other patient populations. Come on. 78% random tested for five years and never had a missed or positive test. You don't have a real results like that. Nobody's got results like that. Well, why is this? Maybe because doctors are smarter. I don't know, not smarter. They have the same rates of addiction as anybody else does, actually. And it's because there's leverage there. The leverage is their practice, their livelihood. It's on the line. And by the way, it isn't just doctors. Commercial pilots have the same kind of approach too. And sometimes lawyers do, but not quite as much as the pilots and the doctors. And why is it pilots and doctors? Because of the concern for the public safety of the addicted person. That's why you get into this. But it's a very important thing. So somebody said to me, well, but that's why all this, what happens afterwards? What happens after they finish? And they do relapse from time to time, but very unusual. But what's most interesting is we asked them, what was the most important thing to you, this is five years after their last mandatory test, five years after the last mandatory test, we asked them, what was the most important thing to you in your getting recovering from this disease? And they had treatment, those treatment that they had at the beginning where they were in the residential treatment mostly, that was very important to them. Twice as high as that was going to AA and NA meetings. Now this is doctors. The doctors are going to the meetings. All of them were essentially are going to meetings. Not as a occasional person, but all of them were going to meetings. Why is that? Why did they ever get that program? How did that happen to be so different from what happens to everybody else? And the answer was that program was not started by experts like me. That program was started by doctors who were themselves in recovery. That's why it's so tough. It's not so tough to punish them. It's so tough because that's the disease we're trying dealing with. And that's what it takes to get people's attention and change their behavior. And I like to think that those doctors in their experience and God bless them are helping us understand the disease and what you do about it and what the recovery is like. And because these doctors are the ones that I've worked with quite exemplary, quite impressive. But anyhow, back to the basic message here. Cunning, baffling and powerful, lifelong and a matter of life and death.
title: ADDICTION: Cunning Baffling Powerful

transcript_whisper: I was abused as a child sexually and I really didn't know how to deal with it. I was in and out of the psych center and heavily medicated and some of my friends were like, hey, why don't you try this? And I did. How did that work out? It numb the pain and it was an escape for a long time. But it ended in me trying to take my own life. I knew I was addicted to things before I started using drugs because they started me on Ritalin when I was a kid, first grade. And I remember just the ups and the downs from that. I would get like a high and then when I would come off of it, it's like I needed more even as a kid, you know? I couldn't really function without it. Being a child and being prescribed to such a strong medication, I feel like it almost wires your brain to be an addict because it's speed. I mean, it helped me concentrate and it's calmed me down, but the real problem was still there. The real problem was I was abused. And so as you got older, you started getting into... Well, it started out weed and then pills. Of course, cocaine, you know, that was a drug of choice because I was on Ritalin my whole life. So I was looking for speed, you know? I was used to functioning at a much faster pace. So this normal life and no drugs, it felt weird. And then it went to alcohol, heroin, crack. Whatever I could get my hands on that would numb the pain, I was going to take it. And I didn't care what it cost me because I was living in turmoil my whole life. So I needed to get away. Did you have any resemblance of a normal life during this time or were you more... I don't even know what a normal life would look like. I've seen it on TV, what people look like normal. And I can't imagine what that's like. I have an idea of what it's like now at 46. I mean, I had dreams of things I desired to do, maybe. But each day I was just trying to get through the day and I want to kill myself. And I was in and out of the psych center my whole entire life. How did you wind up in there? Who would put you there? Would you put yourself there? No, my mother would. My mother and my stepfather and... until they couldn't and then... I would get arrested. I mean... Or I would do something that would put me in the psych center. I usually try to take my life. What helped? Well, I tried to take my life about eight years ago and I was on life support for four days. And when I came out of the medically induced coma that they had me in, I realized it didn't work. And God had me here for a reason. And no matter how many times I would try to take myself out, he wasn't ready for me to leave here. So I got locked in with a church. I got married. My husband's a big influence in my life for knowing Christ. And my church is a big influence in my life. Having a relationship with the Lord. Was that your first time involved in church? It was my first time with a relationship with Jesus Christ. I believed before, but I did not have a relationship. I still was medicated. I was still in therapy and prescribed medications. And I wasn't coming to it with a clear, clear thinking. It seems like you spent a lot of your developmental years in a kind of a fog. Yeah, you could say that. It almost doesn't even seem like it's my life. It seems like I was just there. It wasn't even my life. I was under the influence pretty much since first grade of medications, prescribed medications, or drugs. What are you thinking now? Just wow, how far God has brought me. I'm grateful. I'm grateful to still be alive. Because a lot of my friends aren't. They didn't find your path. They didn't. God chose me. And now I die to myself every day to live for Him. I was seeking God like I was seeking those drugs. So when you quit, was there a detox process that was difficult? Yeah, the detox wasn't as bad as some of the drugs I've come off of. I had dealt with a great deal of pain, so I was taking Suboxone and coming off of cocaine. So it wasn't as bad as it could have been. It was still hard. So where are you at now? A place I never thought I would be. I never knew how to get where I am. I just didn't know how to get to it. People told me, just trusting the Lord. And I did, but I just didn't. I couldn't get over the hump. I couldn't lay everything down. I still wanted to do it my way. But His too, and that didn't work. But you're in a good place now. I'm in a great place now. Great. What's so great about it? I feel free. I feel like all the chains that the enemy had on me are broken off. I feel like I can actually live. How's the living going? It's great. Recovery is hard. It's a hard process. But if you seek the Lord like you were seeking the drugs, it makes it a lot easier. It makes it easier. I mean, I'm just thankful for where I'm at. What is it that people who want to be in recovery but are not, what is it they need to know? That they can do it. It seems impossible. I know they're scared, but they can do it. Why can't they do it? Because if I can do it, I know anybody can do it. If you really want to get clean, you really want to start putting your family first and everyone that loves you, then you can do it. I'll tell you this, I could have done it without God. That's one thing I know. I've tried to do it myself every other way. But until I put Him first, and I mean before everything, I could not do it. That's what changed everything. Thank you. Thank you.
title: April's Story - Recovery and Faith

transcript_whisper: So where does your story begin? Oh, so I guess my childhood, I mean it wasn't the best childhood. Both parents were pretty abusive to each other, but not so much to us. We were both alcoholics and I think just kind of seeing them pretty much beat up on each other all the time. It just really gave me an unstable environment anyways. So moving forward, I really just wanted to not be like them so much that I just focused on not being an alcoholic. I was like oblivious to everything else and then before I knew it, I was hooked on Percocet. My friend's mom, we were 15, she would give us Percocet to give us energy to clean. So I just thought it was something fun to do and then before I knew it, I knew what withdrawal was. Yeah, yeah. And then so of course that leads to just the whole chasing the high and doctor shopping and just chaos. Before that, I was 13, my dad passed away from drinking. So that was something that just should have rocked me and it should have been talked about, but it wasn't. And it just kind of got suppressed. So then I'm still in, I go into the pills and all that and I'm partying and doing everything I'm not supposed to do. And then by the time I'm 21, my mom just randomly passes away and that's due to alcohol too. So I'm just mad. I'm frustrated. I don't understand. And then I end up in jail and I go to a back in front of the judge and the girl that was going before me was like, oh, he denied me for this program and I was going up for the same program. And I was like, oh man, and he gave it to me and he said, you know what, I'm going to give you enough rope, either you're going to hang yourself or you're not. And if you come back in here, I'm giving you all your time. Well, it was a faith based program and it really gave me the foundation I needed. But then again, I got out, I had my daughter and I just started having this, oh, I got this attitude and I did not have it. And before I knew it, I was, you know, popping Adderall and that led to meth. And then I lost my daughter and then I was in like a deeper hole than I was before. And I was just like, oh, here I am again, like stuck on something else. And I thought heroin and pills were hard to get off of, but meth was just, it just, I don't even know. It was like, I was so confident and I was like feeling myself, but then it slowly like started getting worse and worse. And my now husband was actually my drug dealer. So that in itself is amazing to me. But yeah, so we were on meth and we were living that great life. We thought we had the cars and the money and all of that, but we were just still empty on the inside. I mean, I didn't have my daughter. I just felt hopeless really like I just didn't want to be here. So he, we lost the house. We lost the cars. We didn't have water. We didn't have power. Like we were just barely even making it. And finally one day my husband was like, I'm done. And I was like, what do you mean you're done? And he was like, I'm not doing it anymore. And I was like, okay, well, he did. He stuck to it and he stopped. And I just, I couldn't still like a year in of him being clean. I was still using and then I picked up a gambling habit on top of that. And yeah, he just, he stuck by me and he knew I was using and he just was really leaning on God at the time. And I was like, well, I did the God thing and it didn't work for me. Like look at me now. So I was mad really that he was getting it and I wasn't. And I ended up going to an outpatient program where they just, I don't even know, they just saw something in me that I didn't see in myself. And I mean, I put them through the ringer. They, they just, I would fill urine screens. I would, you know, just do everything I wasn't supposed to do. And they would still be like, you know what, it's fine. It's fine. Just keep coming back. Until one day Chad comes home and I'm about to use and he just catches me red handed. And I remember thinking two days before that, like, man, if Chad would just catch me, I swear I'll stop. I swear I'll stop and lo and behold, he caught me. And yeah, he just, he was really calm. He didn't yell at me. He didn't chastise me. He was like, you know, your daughter deserves to have you in her life. And he just said, I really advise you throw that away. And I was like, yeah, right. Well, that was two days before Christmas. So I said, I'm going to get through the holidays and I'll stop. And I did. And it's been great. I was already done. Like I was just sick of it. You know, I was just tired of hiding it. I was tired of feeling like I just was never going to get out of it. You know, I was tired of being depressed and I just wanted to be on the same page as my husband. We got married. Like he asked me to marry him while I was still using and he knew I was still using. I was like, what is this guy doing? Like it's not going to work. But um, so throughout all that had been five years that I was completely absent from my daughter's life. Like they, her aunt didn't want me to be around her or anything. And at the time I was like, oh, she's just, she's wrong. She's just trying to steal my kid. And like that was the drugs talking. I mean, golly, I couldn't even pass a hair follicle test for her. You know, I'm sitting there trying to figure out ways to clean my hair to be able to pass instead of just stopping using. Like it was crazy. And um, so that was a year and a half ago I got to see my daughter for the first time and it's great. And everything is just really falling into place. At that point, it was just like I didn't want to be there. I had no idea how to cope, how to be a person, how to allow somebody else to love me, how to love anybody else. You know, I lost my brother.
