Whenever I was in prison, I was like, you know what, no, I didn't, I didn't live for nothing. You know, even though I don't just feel like I deserve to be here because of who I was before. I lived for something and I can live for my kids too. So my addiction lasted from the age of 12, 13 years old to 26. Whenever I was 26, that's when I changed, I decided to change my life. I had gone to prison, I got out of prison and I was just, I wanted something different, you know, trying to stay high in order to escape everything. And you think you have this false sense of healing and you're just, you're reaching for healing and you're reaching for healing, but you're never able to grasp it because all you're doing is destroying yourself. I wanted that healing in my life. I wanted to overcome the traumas in my life that I had never given myself a chance to face. It wasn't until I decided to change and to do something different that I realized that's when the healing began. Like that's when I could actually overcome all the things that I had gone through. I made that decision, but I made that decision and I also had no support. Like I had nobody to back me up with those decisions that I was making, but I just, I seen something in myself that never gave up through everything that I faced, everything that I went through. I didn't give up on myself through all of that. I didn't love myself. I didn't have self-worth, but I noticed I didn't never give up and that was for a reason. So making those decisions, like I just decided whatever it was going to take, wherever it was going to lead me, even if it wasn't everything that I was wanting, I felt like I was worth at least giving myself a shot. So I got out and I had nowhere to go. I actually went right back into my addiction the first two weeks I was out of prison, but it was different this time. This time it didn't feel like an escape. It felt completely wrong. Like this is, I told myself when I was in prison, like we're going to get out and we're going to do it all different. And it felt different when I said it then. And when I got out and went right back to it, it felt different then as well. Like it wasn't for me anymore. And I struggled. I was bouncing. I was couch surfing, bouncing around from this person's house to that person's house. They were all using an active addiction. And I ended up at one of my friend's house who was doing a lot better in her life, you know, in her addiction recovery. And I told her everything that was going on. And I was like, you know, I messed up, but this doesn't feel like me anymore. And she herself was just like, you know what? I believe you and I want to see where you can go in your life. And her and her husband actually allowed me to stay with them for a month or two. And then I met a friend who traveled working in the pipe field and they had seen how well I was doing. And they were like, you know what? Come with me. I'll help you get a job. So I just leapt. I was like, this is it. This is the opportunity that I've been waiting for. I'm nervous. I don't know where this is going to lead, but I'm going to go for it. So I started traveling on the road. I was a pipe fitter helper and an expediter and that's all I needed. I just needed somebody to believe in me for the first time in my life. I needed opportunity and I needed to believe in myself and it made all the difference. How do you get to know? They are the most resilient people I have ever seen in my life. They were three and four at the time of this. Now they're 13, 14. And I have not seen them skip a beat. They are amazing. They're thriving. They're both so smart. They make straight A's sometimes in school. If not A's, A's and B's, they're excelling in their lives. And I admire them so much. They're beautiful. They're great. How do you get to know? Now, oh, you know, I never thought I'd see this side of life. I always thought, you know, getting sober and overcoming what I did, I thought my life would be okay. I thought it would be like mediocre, but God had other plans for me. I'm actually a board member and a case manager of an organization called Offensive, where I get to give back to people struggling like I once was. It's beautiful. I get to work closely with other organizations in my town. Jailers Boys, they're amazing. You know, if it weren't for them, you know, posting about this event right here, I wouldn't have even thought to come and tell my story. But I've got to see the amazing work that they do in the community. You know, I've been able to turn something so terrible in my life, all the family trauma, the dysfunction, the addiction. I've been able to turn it around to do good to help other people who are struggling and just be a beacon of hope. Offensive helps a lot of women. They help a lot of men as well. But I personally work alongside with the women. A lot of the women we work with, you know, have been in severe abusive relationships, family, you know, domestic, have been sexually trafficked, you know, lost in their own addictions and things like that. And so it's been a blessing for me myself to be able to give these women a little bit of hope in their lives and to see them overcome their barriers and achieve their goals. And it shows how resilient we can really be. I never thought I'd be on the other side of this. In my life, I was sure that I was going to die in addiction. I was sure that that's the only person that I could be. I never believed that I could be somebody giving back to somebody else. Like, you see these people with these badges and your addiction, and those are the people you're going to for help, and it's... You don't look at them and say, oh, well, I can do that. But now I am doing that. I am that person with the badge now. I am that person that can help somebody else. When first so long, that wasn't an option for me. I had fully convinced myself that. Because when you have the life experience, you're able to reach these people in a way, say somebody who just goes to school and they're learning from a book. You can learn about it all day long, but until you've lived it, you have no idea what that person is actually facing mentally and the challenges that they are facing in themselves and how can you combat the issue without fully understanding what it looks like to that person. So having the life experience, and I've had so many women tell me, we'll come to you and we'll talk to you because you know us. You've been us. You understand how I actually feel and what I'm actually going through. And with that, that's where lasting change happens. That's where real relation happens. That's when they actually have hope. Because you're not just a person with a book in front of them. You've been there, you've done that, and you've overcome it. So maybe they can too. Thank you. Thank you.
title: Addiction, Homicide, Trauma: I'm Still Standing - Gabrielle Francis' Story

And I kept the party going as much as possible. But after a while, you know, the party caused a lot of problems. There was a day when I was, you know, Sunday brunch. You go out. It was a football season, so we were going to go watch the game. We went to brunch first. I always loved wine. I could finish a bottle of wine in one sitting. Seven days in Harris County. And that was the scariest thing that ever happened to me. I slept on the floor. There were no beds. They didn't have any more cots. They didn't care. They didn't care. transcript_whisper: ago I was really, really sick. I had been diagnosed with fibromyalgia after the side of my only brother. My body hurt for about seven years. I had two small children and I was putting myself through college so the doctors prescribed me opiates. And I ended up abusing those pills and being completely dependent upon them. I ended up getting in trouble with the law by driving home after having some alcohol. And so I was in a spot where it was live or die and I decided to live. My kids had to go live with my mom for a little while and the night after they left I fell apart. I ended up getting so intoxicated I had to be carried home. And not only was my body dying, my organs were shutting down but my brain was dying and I had about a three second short term memory on a good day. I tried to go to work that night and ended up with my head resting on the toilet at O'Malley Steak Pub in Palmer Lake. And I mentioned that because that's where I did most of my recovery. I know a lot of people have the privilege of going to treatment or something like that and finding support. And I had isolated so much because of violence and my substance use that I didn't have any support. I didn't have any insurance because I was a waitress and I could not go to treatment. So I went into the doctor and I said I need your help to get off of these pills because if I don't I'm going to die. And I knew I was going to die probably within the next few days. And so I used what's called harm reduction and I used medicated assisted treatment to help me come off of the medication that I was on. And it took about two months for my withdrawal symptoms to stop. But after that is when I had to start my counseling for my DUI classes. And today I still see that same counselor and I have continued to change my behaviors every single day since then. So medically assisted. Yeah. Is that like Suboxone? For some people at Suboxone one of the medications I was on was actually methadone. And so that's another medication that people use. However, since that's what I was abusing it was obviously not a good choice to help me come off of it. Even though I did cut down what I had left until it was gone. The doctor also gave me a clonidine patch which is for blood pressure and some Xanax and told me to use that during the acute withdrawal symptoms. And so that's what I did. And then after I stopped shaking I started coming off of the Percocet which is the other medication I was on. And I started practicing yoga as well. I got almost all of my medicine from the doctor. There was a short time where I did buy some methadone from somebody. But all of the Percocet I got from the doctor. So yeah. And it was before fentanyl was in everything luckily. They actually tried to put me on fentanyl patch. But it thankfully didn't work well with me. So I ended up just on the methadone and Percocet. It's interesting because the first time I actually used substances was when I was about, I don't know, three or four. And a friend at church gave me some Tums and he was a grownup and he was like, here this is candy. And so that kind of started an unhealthy relationship with medication. And a few years later his son who was a teenager assaulted me while I was sleeping. And I was about five or six when that happened. I didn't tell anybody until years later but I ended up confronting him about it and letting him know that I remembered and that I hoped he never did it to anybody else. And then a few years later my parents were married and they had five kids. They ended up divorcing and my mom remarried. From that time on I was raised in a home that was terrifying. The first time I was strangled I was 11 for saying something I wasn't supposed to. Everything in my life was controlled from the clothes that I wore to how I did my hair to the food that we were allowed to eat. In high school I ended up getting a boyfriend after experiencing a second sexual assault. But this one was in the hallway in front of all of my classmates while they were just walking by and laughing and calling me names. I got a boyfriend and we ended up getting pregnant after a few months and having a little boy. We ended up breaking up, getting back together, breaking up and eventually staying apart. And then after I was with him I dated another person who was quite controlling and then I started a job in the big city near the little town that I grew up in. On my first day of work my trainer invited me back to his house. I was 19. He made me a drink and I remember about 10 minutes. I was sexually assaulted all night and had no idea that that's what was happening until years later. After that I was like on a violent roller coaster of using substances to feel better and putting myself in dangerous situations. And then bad things happening. When I was 23 I went to the bar that I worked at one night and this really handsome guy came in. We ended up getting married a few months later and having a daughter. When we separated the only thing he left me with was that daughter and a burned scar on my arm which is now covered with an incredible tattoo that says you have no power over me. Because I want to remind everybody and every substance that I am the one in control of my own life. After we divorced I got with somebody even more dangerous than he was and then yet again. After my third marriage that's actually the marriage that I found recovery in. So I was married to somebody who was unkind to me and also physically abusive to my children. I learned what sexual violence was and I learned how I was adding to my own suffering. It was not my fault that people hurt me especially when I was a child but it was absolutely my responsibility to learn from it and prevent it from happening again which is what I didn't do until I was about 35 years old. And it walks you through basically my recovery journey and helps people learn to come out of fight or flight to deescalate their nervous system because intimate partner violence not only contributes to mental health challenges but it can affect our physical health as well. Today I spend time with my husband, my friends. I have the best job in the world that I absolutely love to go to every day that I actually helped create. So today I'm where I never ever thought that I would be. People that are enduring domestic violence right now, what's that thing they need to know? title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE - UNBROKEN

Like because I was too lost in my world that making them dinner was the last thing on my mind. My kids witnessed severe abuse between me and my husband. Knockout dragouts. transcript_whisper: The part of the brain that gets hijacked by anything that can spike dopamine levels too high is the limbic system, a very primitive all or nothing fight or flight part of the brain. And when it gets hijacked, it will defend and seek that which it thinks it needs to survive vehemently. You haven't eaten food for 12 hours. You have tunnel vision, your dopamine plummets, your moody, you will push over small children to get to food. There's a saying, the world is three meals away from utter chaos. It's the same thing that happens when we become addicted to anything, whether that be a substance or behavior, we will say and do anything to defend our need for it. Not to mention, once that part of the brain becomes hijacked, it sends a signal to our prefrontal cortex, which is the part of the brain that gets attached to things that are good for our survival, like people, places and things that care for us and nourish us. But when the limbic system gets hijacked by something that increases dopamine levels too high, it sends a signal to the prefrontal cortex that says, oh, this is really good for your survival. So you should attach to it. So when I hear people vehemently defending their need for cannabis or the reasons that they use it, whether it be medicinal or for pain or any other, I always think about how hijacked their limbic system is and how that reward pathway has sent a signal to their prefrontal cortex that will come up with all kinds of rational and irrational reasons to defend their need for it. There is a state of mind called hypofrontality. Hypofrontality is caused when the frontal lobe down regulates, meaning it moves the electrical activity and blood flow into the limbic system. When somebody is high or intoxicated or scared, the brain mobilizes to either get what it thinks it needs to survive or to down regulate and react out of fear. So when people are using intoxicants or engaging in a behavior that spikes dopamine levels too high, limbic system lights up, the frontal lobe down regulates, almost turning off. The frontal lobe is the part of the brain that has emotion regulation, impulse control, the ability to feel empathy and use abstract rational reasoning. So when somebody is using a substance, especially every day or every other day, their frontal lobe is always down regulated in some shape or form, which means they don't have the kind of normal access to their executive functioning skills that they should have. That means they're going to respond in very immature, selfish, self-centered, self-focusing ways, which is one of the reasons why family members feel so disconnected and don't understand what's going on. It's not their family member. It's literally just an addictive limbic system that is rationalizing and moving toward finding that thing that it thinks it needs to survive, whether that be a drug or a behavior. I was a very rule-following, anxious, wanting to make all a kind of kid until family moved and my parents got divorced and I really wanted to fit in. And so this really cute boy tells me to go to a party and somebody handed me a beer. What I didn't know when I drank that beer is that I have a genetic predisposition that predisposes me to becoming addicted to anything that spikes my dopamine levels. And unfortunately, the beer did. So I kept moving when I was a kid because of all our family dysfunction and I took summer school classes to get to know other kids. Who takes summer school classes, usually the kids who are making poor decisions. So I met a lot of great kids who were making some pretty poor decisions and hung out with them and used a lot of the substances that they did. I really wanted to fit in and then I wanted to take away my negative feelings. And unfortunately, drugs and alcohol are great for doing that until you get addicted and they're the cause of the negative feelings. So I had an overdose when I was 18. And I picked up the phone, the thousand pound phone, and I called my mom who helped me get into rehab. When I graduated from rehab, I went to a halfway house for about six months and I got stable. And that's when I went back to college and I started studying everything I could get my hands on about the brain and addiction. And it was a really cool period of time to study because all of these really cool functional MRI studies were being published. And now I do that as a hobby. I constantly look at fMRI studies. And what I'm seeing is that there are a variety of different high risk behavior that cause hypofrontality. And when your frontal lobe is shut off more than it's on, it creates what doctors call a state of acquired narcissism. The keyword is acquired. When you don't have the part of the brain on that can have empathy, problem solve, make good decisions, use abstract reasoning, then you're really self focused, have difficulty regulating emotion. And so you end up looking like a very self absorbed, self centered human that has difficulty attuning to others. That's when people might call you a dumb stoner or a selfish self centered jerk. But the truth is, without the drugs and alcohol and your frontal lobe turning on, which is the part of the brain that actually attunes to others can calm yourself down, can delay gratification. When that part of the brain is on, you're not narcissistic. You're other focused. You have the ability to stay in your adult energy and have good relationships. Those are unfortunately delayed or disabled when we're using that part of the brain is just not as accessible to us. When you look at the brain in the central nervous system, specifically we focus in on dopamine, because every chemical of abuse out there has in common an increase in dopamine. That's what changes the brain chemistry and hijacks a brain, specifically the limbic system that gets addicted. But every drug also does something else to the brain or body. For instance, alcohol increases GABA, which is our brain's neurotransmitter that calms us down. That's why alcohol can calm us down. Also makes us feel really good GABA plus dopamine. Serotonin is another neurotransmitter that our body helps us to regulate our feelings and make us feel more calm. Now cocaine increases serotonin and dopamine, central nervous system stimulant. So we feel really, really good because of the combination of those two. If you look at any chemical out there, marijuana is another example. It increases dopamine, but it also binds to endocannabinoid receptor sites. We have those all over our brain and body, especially in our gut. And they also increase things like GABA. So they are a replacement central nervous system, depressant. So of course, you can probably stop alcohol if you try using kush or any other synthetic substance that binds to the same receptor sites. But you're not actually solving the problem. You're just switching from one addiction to the other. And that's what things like harm reduction are. When somebody's addicted to fentanyl or heroin, of course, reducing harm to methadone is very helpful because then you don't have the dangerous and debilitating withdrawal symptoms. But now you're hooked on methadone or suboxone for potentially decades, unless you go through the same withdrawal process to get off of them, which many don't because it's so painful. It's been an interesting journey. The first half of my 26-year career thus far was a lot of alcohol and drug issues. The average age was about 15, 16 years old of my clients. Today, what I'm seeing, average age is about 12, 13, 14. And it's a combination of addictive technology, addictive video games. Some of it is early nicotine or alcohol use or marijuana use, but it's more of a combination today. And what I'm also seeing is that the incidence and frequency and intensity of cannabis addiction are skyrocketing. Back in the year I was born, 1970, the average amount of THC in marijuana is about 2%. Today, we're seeing anywhere between 56% and 99%. So the rate at which people are becoming addicted is skyrocketing in proportion to how much THC is synthesized or grown into the plant. So where it used to take maybe two to three years to start becoming or showing signs of cannabis addiction, now it's happening within three to four months. And a percentage of people who used marijuana back in 1970 would have a psychotic episode based upon that. But the percentage was about 2%. 2% of all people who tried weed would have a psychotic episode. Now today, we're seeing that go up to in the 20 to 25th percentile because there's so much more THC. It's just much more potent. So we're seeing more and more people having psychosis. But it's not just what I saw in the 70s or not 70s, but 80s when I was a teenager. You know, it used to be you might have a psychotic episode, go into the hospital for an overnight stay, come out and you're fine. Your brain was able to heal and adjust. And today we're not seeing that. I'm seeing people go into mental hospitals forever changed. I'm seeing parents who are having to figure out how to institutionalize their college age adult children because they can't function in society anymore. I'm seeing kids who are so sick from hyperemesis that they can't eat and keep weight on. I'm seeing people who have chronic pain or chronic anxiety use marijuana to treat those illnesses, but end up with four to five times the amount of chronic pain and not only increased anxiety, but now also psychosis and paranoia that comes with that. Medicine in the term of cannabis is not a real term. It's a marketing term. And the idea is addiction for profit. Our industries don't care what's happening to the brains of their clients. They just want to line their pockets with as much cash as they possibly can, regardless of the public health crisis. And what I'm starting to see is more and more people are starting to know someone that has this issue. The percentage of people who used to become addicted to marijuana back in the 70s was about 9%. Today we're in the 20th to 25th percentile of the rates of addiction. We're also seeing a large percentage of the population who are not using recreationally just for fun. They're getting hooked on it and they're getting hooked quickly. So now they're using on a much more consistent, regular basis, suffering consequences, but are not able to stop. So that's what I'm seeing now in clinical practice. And when I watch the states who are legalizing it, we know that the reason they are is because lobbyists are sharing with politicians very cherry-picked studies on how these things can help or medicate when in actuality the totality of the research on cannabis. And please know I have read every journal article that I can get my hands on from when they started publishing it, but the totality of this research shows that it not only does not work well for treating things like anxiety, depression, or chronic pain, but it exacerbates those issues and causes deleterious effects to the brain, the body, self-worth, self-esteem, academics, career, even IQ, as well as genetic changes that these substances can affect on the body. I have a nonprofit called knowyourneuro.org and I create videos for kindergartners all the way up through 12th grade. It's for schools. I've got about 65 school districts in the United States and two schools in the UK that use it. It's a free prevention program. And so I do a lot of podcast interviews. My books too, the website is based upon my books. I'm an author of the Neuro-Whereabouts Guide for Parents and Children's Book series called Know Your Neuro Adventures of a Growing Brain.
